One of the great weakneses of modern times. Someone produces a theory backed up with a computer model and it's acted upon as fact. This is not a criticism of the scientists per se. They are vital for understanding the world around us. The questions they are trying to answer are often complex. However, in regards to linear wave theory I actually think it was poor science - how can you ignore huge ships going missing and some- when found- actually showed signs they were impacted by a huge force. And then the eye witness accounts from mariners. Not seeing the woods for the trees springs to mind. I feel the covid outbreak has shown further problems with basing our reactions on a theory backed up with a computer model. It gives some people the illusion that they know what's going to happen.

Humm I'm slightly disappointed by the video... you didn't mention the most cool part about these rogue waves - they are solitary wave capable of travelling over vast distance. This is a surprising fact because waves usually dissipate with the absence of a source (i.e. flattens out as it travels) - provided they are linear. It would also be very interesting to mention how these waves share the same principle in nonlinear optics.

I'm surprised the phenomenon of a rogue wave was only recently affirmed by the science community.  With so many technicians in the Navy I would have thought that someone would have previously experienced it and recorded it.  I've spent about 280 days at sea on commercial fishing ships in the North Pacific and the Gulf of Alaska.  While the rogue wave is rare, I did once experience a surprising wave that was unusually large and it nearly capsized our ship, a sword fishing vessel based in Hawaii.  Four of us were on deck picking gear in rough weather somewhere between Dutch Harbor and Hawaii.  The ship was riding the trough when the wave suddenly appeared and broke. I became completely submerged from the head down, and fortunately trapped against the ship as it listed well past our comfort zone.  After the wave made initial contact, throwing the first mate and I against the pilot house, I found myself completely under water next to the ship for a few seconds as the ship righted itself. Other crew members were also lucky and got stuck near the stern's bait shed.  Our vessel had about 4 feet of freeboard, and the pilot house roof was nearly two stories above sea level, a ship with about 89 ton displacement, 20 foot beam, if I remember correctly.  The top of the wave hit the pilot house windows.  After 37 days of fishing our hold was mostly full, holding about 40,000 lbs. of fish and ice, well packed in bins.  The extra mass may have helped to kept us from rolling over into Davy Jones's Locker.  As far as I am concerned, rogue waves are real.  I've been inside one.

I think a problem with this episode is that people watching it might confuse linear algebraic equations with linear differential equations, and they are not the same thing.

I'd also note that not all nonlinear systems show chaos, they need to be "sufficiently complicated", as outlined here: https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=P1kCtNr-pJsC&pg=PA460&lpg=PA460&dq=for+the+record,+the+criterion+is+this:+classical+mechanics&source=bl&ots=giUs2bJxBZ&sig=2YBfaCbpHGJuJQGCPgsQwKu5ZnI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVkbOkoa_MAhVIJMAKHaUWD0sQ6AEIJDAB#v=onepage&q=for%20the%20record%2C%20the%20criterion%20is%20this%3A%20classical%20mechanics&f=false

Anyone who's spent a significant amount of time on the water has seen them. They don't have to be monster waves. All you need are two waves coming together or some waves traveling at an angle to the others. Those are the weirdest!

You see these huge lines of triangular peaks coming at your boat. Again, if you're in six-foot seas, you aren't going to get hundred-foot rogue waves, but you will certainly get occasional twelve foot waves.

You'll never notice them if they're a hundred yards away because that's not what you're worrying about and they only last a second. You DEFINITELY notice them when they happen right in front of your boat. There's plenty of video footage of rogue waves on Deadliest Catch. The boat's heading into the wind and into the waves when the captain shouts, "ROGUE WAVE!" and a double-sized wave crashes over the boat from a different direction.
